Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Fluid Transport and Fluid-Rock Interactions Preserved in Two Serpentinite Melanges in the Guatemala Suture Zone
Award.AbstractNarration:
Subduction channel fluids are responsible for modification of metamorphic blocks, crystallization of vein rocks, serpentinization of the overlying mantle wedge and ultimately the flux melting that spawns arc volcanism. We propose to extend our studies of the serpentinite mélanges of the Guatemala Suture Zone (GSZ) to elucidate this record of mass transport by fluid as recorded in the rocks. The GSZ encompasses two serpentinite mélanges that preserve the elements described above. One system on the south side of the Motagua fault records very cold and wet conditions within the subduction channel, represented by lawsonite eclogite blocks formed at ~2.6 GPa and 450-500ºC. The other system north of the fault represents somewhat warmer but still wet conditions preserved in epidote-eclogite blocks, with peak metamorphism at 500-600°C and ~ 2 GPa. Both mélanges carry fragments of vein systems that formed within the overlying serpentinizing mantle peridotites; these include jadeitite, omphacitite, albitite, and mica-dominant rocks that contain a strong signature of fluids from altered oceanic crust and subducted sediment. Detailed petrologic and geochemical characterization of representative rocks is proposed for major, minor, and trace-element geochemistry and Sr-Nd isotopic systematics for this research, with a focus on B, Li, Be concentrations and isotopes. Textures, mineralogy, and chemical composition will be utilized to sort between processes that occurred during subduction as opposed to later exhumation.

Intellectual Merit: Subduction is a fundamental process on Earth that recycles surface matter into the interior mantle and contributes to growth of continental crust. However, details of fluid-mediated mass transport and alteration in subduction zones are poorly understood and require further resolution. Careful study of preserved subduction zones, where both fluid precipitates and hydrated mantle wedge rocks are preserved, will contribute important insights on this issue. It is proposed to build upon results of a previously NSF-funded project by detailed chemical analysis of minerals in rocks preserved in serpentinite mélanges in the GSZ with the following objectives: (1) Characterize the mantle wedge protolith by study of the relict phases; (2) Analyze serpentinite minerals for major, minor and trace elements with particular attention to B, Li, and Be (and isotopic signatures) and textural settings to assess fluid modification of protolith and distinction between changes produced during subduction versus during exhumation; (3) Analyze minerals from vein rocks (e.g., jadeitite, omphacitite, mica-rock, etc.) with the same approach to determine the solute load of fluids traversing the subduction channel and entering the mantle wedge, as well as the relative timing based on textures and mineral assemblages. Using fluid-mineral partition coefficients we will estimate fluid composition entering the mantle wedge. (4) Utilize Sr-Nd isotopic data to assess sources of lithologic components (e.g., mantle vs. recycled continental or sedimentary sources). The proposed research will enhance understanding of fluid transport from subduction channels to the mantle wedge.

Broader Impacts: These include the collaboration of researchers at universities and museums, involvement of students and scientists in many countries, including those in Central America, support of teacher training and geological training in Guatemala, links with archaeological studies on Caribbean-area jade, connections among research groups, and extensive outreach to both the media and the public via interviews, articles and Museum web-sites aimed both at student education and dissemination of our activities, results, and data.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Guatemala Suture Zone (GSZ) cuts east-west across Guatemala in Central America.  It is a major strike slip fault similar to the San Andreas Fault in California and has undergone1100 km or more left lateral displacement.  It and its associated faults continue to the east as the northern boundary of the Caribbean Plate along which major earthquakes occur from time to time including the disastrous 2010 event in Haiti.  But the GSZ is more complicated than it at first appears.  It also was a major convergent system since 140 million years ago, and possibly earlier, which means it was the site of subduction of oceanic crust beneath a volcanic arc as well as the site of a major continental collision.  This kind of plate boundary is called a transpressional system, and it contains an enormous variety of rocks including volcanic and intrusive igneous rocks, sedimentary rocks of all kinds, and, of great interest to us, metamorphic rocks, some of which formed very deep in the earth and are called eclogites.  These eclogites are encapsulated within serpentinites, which are hydrated fragments of the earth’s upper mantle.  These serpentinites, in turn, host other interesting rocks including jade (strictly speaking, “jadeitite”), the rock so prized by the ancient Olmec and Maya cultures.  The many kinds of igneous rocks contain information of the plate tectonic environment where they originated.  The eclogites contain information on when oceanic crust was subducted into the mantle.  The serpentinites contain information on the processes that occurred in the mantle above the subducted oceanic crust (called the mantle wedge).  All rocks, including the jade, contain information on the chemistry of fluids that passed from the subducted oceanic crust through the mantle wedge.  The passage of these fluids through the mantle is, in turn, part of the process that produces the magmas that generate the volcanic arcs that lie above every subduction zone.

         Our general goal was to further understand the complex history of the GSZ, which in turn would help provide us with information on the interactions between subducted ocean crust, the sediments that may or may not get carried down with the ocean crust, and the processes that occurred within the overlying mantle wedge. Our dating of eclogites indicates subduction occurred over at least 80 million years (140-60 million years).  Our chemical analyses of rocks generated during and before this subduction cycle indicates they formed in a bewildering variety of environments including the ocean floor, island arcs, oceanic islands and the basins behind island arcs.  So we conclude that subduction was accompanied by collisions between volcanic island arcs, oceanic islands and the subduction zone, that there was an opening of an ocean basin behind a volcanic arc, and there was a final collision of an arc with the North American Continent about 60 million years ago.  All of these events were accompanied by hundreds of kilometers of strike-slip motion, which carried rocks very similar to those of the GSZ to the east where they are presently exposed in islands like the Dominican Republic.

         Fluids were released from the subduction zone while the basalts were deeply buried and transformed into eclogites.  These same fluids change the rocks above the subduction zone from dry olivine-rich rocks called peridotites to serpentinites, which are dominated by water-bearing minerals like antigorite.  These fluids also altered the dry minerals (garnet, pyroxene) that characterize eclogites into minerals that contain water within them (mica, amphibole, epidote, etc.).  Finally, the fluids produced veins, including veins made of jade, but other minerals as well.  We analyzed all these rocks and their constituent minerals by measuring their chemical compositions, including the concentrations of elements that occur in low abundances (trace elements such as Zirconium, Titanium, Niobium, Lanthanum) and the isotopic ratios of elements such as Strontium, Neodymium, Hafnium, Boron and Lithium.  These measurements have led us to conclude the fluids that traversed the mantle wedge and helped generate the overlying volcanoes originated from altered basalts and sediments and also had a strong sea-water signature.  The basalts, before their alteration, were probably generated from a mantle that was unusually depleted (i.e. peridotite that had previously partially melted to release earlier generations of basalt).

         We have used all these data to put together the plate tectonic history of the GSZ as well as the evolution of the rocks of the GSZ during subduction and subsequent exhumation.
